title: U.S. Presidents
description: How well do you know the leaders of the United States? Test your presidential knowledge!

questions.question: Who was the first President of the United States?
questions.explanation: George Washington served as the first president from 1789 to 1797. He is often called the 'Father of His Country.'

questions.question: Which president is famous for the quote 'Ask not what your country can do for you'?
questions.explanation: John F. Kennedy spoke these famous words during his inaugural address on January 20, 1961, inspiring a generation of Americans to public service.

questions.question: Which president issued the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing enslaved people in Confederate states?
questions.explanation: Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863, declaring enslaved people in Confederate states to be free.

questions.question: Which president led the country during most of World War II?
questions.explanation: Franklin D. Roosevelt led the U.S. through most of WWII but died in April 1945, just months before the war ended. He served an unprecedented four terms.

questions.question: Who was the first president to live in the White House?
questions.explanation: John Adams moved into the White House in November 1800. George Washington never lived there, as it was not completed during his presidency.

questions.question: Which president is known for the Louisiana Purchase, which doubled the size of the United States?
questions.explanation: Thomas Jefferson purchased the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 for about $15 million, roughly 4 cents per acre.

questions.question: Which president resigned from office due to the Watergate scandal?
questions.explanation: Richard Nixon resigned on August 9, 1974, becoming the only U.S. president to resign from office. Gerald Ford then became president.

questions.question: Which president's wife was known as 'Lady Bird'?
questions.explanation: Claudia 'Lady Bird' Johnson was the wife of President Lyndon B. Johnson. She was a champion of environmental beautification and the Highway Beautification Act.

questions.question: Before becoming president, Dwight D. Eisenhower was famous for his role as what?
options: A Supreme Allied Commander in WWII
questions.explanation: Eisenhower served as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe during WWII, leading the D-Day invasion of Normandy in June 1944.

questions.question: Theodore Roosevelt was the youngest person to become president. How old was he when he took office?
questions.explanation: Theodore Roosevelt became president at age 42 after the assassination of William McKinley in 1901. He remains the youngest person to hold the office.

questions.question: Which president established the National Park Service in 1916?
questions.explanation: Woodrow Wilson signed the National Park Service Organic Act in 1916. However, Theodore Roosevelt is often credited with greatly expanding the national parks system before that.

questions.question: Which two presidents both died on July 4, 1826, the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence?
questions.explanation: Thomas Jefferson and John Adams both died on July 4, 1826, exactly 50 years after the adoption of the Declaration of Independence. They had been both rivals and friends.

questions.question: Which president famously said, 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself'?
questions.explanation: Franklin D. Roosevelt spoke these words in his first inaugural address in 1933, during the depths of the Great Depression, rallying the nation's spirits.

questions.question: Who was the tallest U.S. president, standing at 6 feet 4 inches?
questions.explanation: Abraham Lincoln stood at 6 feet 4 inches, making him the tallest U.S. president in history. His height and stovepipe hat made him an unmistakable figure.

questions.question: Which president was a former Hollywood actor before entering politics?
questions.explanation: Ronald Reagan appeared in over 50 films before entering politics. He served as Governor of California before becoming the 40th president in 1981.
